So, Shawn,
you've been in the CISO role for a while,

and you've been in the security industry
for quite some time.

So, as we've talked about, CISOs evolve
from the
GRC technician perspective.
I can't

remember where I heard it, but I remember
someone saying a CISO saying,

I just want to do the CISO job,
meaning security.

And I'm like, well,
that's not what our job is anymore.

Regardless of if there's regulation
that's being proposed or will be there.

There, there absolutely
has to be some sort of regulation

throughout the world that's going
to kind of force that situation.
We'll call it the SOCs of
of IT security.

So I think that there's going to be
a natural evolution of CISOs
advising boards.

Advising companies
because they need that third party

And I don't know how that's going
to be shaped, whether they're going to be.
on boards, or advisory to a board,
or private sessions.
And there's, there's

the board training is happening

There's a couple other offerings
that kinda get there. But,

I think if we look at that,
we as well know

certifications
have a role in our industry.
Sure. And we there's value to them.

And there's also some people leaning
a little too much on them saying, “oh,

I have the CERT.” That means that day

And so that's the concern
I have kind of with the certification
of the training piece.

It needs to be ongoing of
of the security industry.

If you work in finance or accounting,
you have to learn something new
once a year.

If you work in IT,
you learn something new every day.

If you work in security, you got to learn

So that same type of impact

needs some sort of recurring education

a general practices for security defined

not even our industry,

of a fixed base operations
scheduling to a truck,

into the boards
risk appetite that you have to tailor.

an ear
